0.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
0.text: Good evening. And welcome to the third and last presidential debate of 2008, sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates. I'm Bob Schieffer of CBS News.
0.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

1.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
1.text: The rules tonight are simple. The subject is domestic policy. I will divide the next hour-and-a-half into nine-minute segments.
1.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

2.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
2.text: I will ask a question at the beginning of each segment. Each candidate will then have two minutes to respond, and then we'll have a discussion.
2.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

3.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
3.text: I'll encourage them to ask follow-up questions of each other. If they do not, I will.
3.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

4.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
4.text: The audience behind me has promised to be quiet, except at this moment, when we welcome Barack Obama and John McCain.
4.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

5.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
5.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

6.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
6.text: By now, we've heard all the talking points, so let's try to tell the people tonight some things that they -- they haven't heard. Let's get to it.
6.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

7.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
7.text: Another very bad day on Wall Street, as both of you know. Both of you proposed new plans this week to address the economic crisis.
7.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

8.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
8.text: Sen. McCain, you proposed a $52 billion plan that includes new tax cuts on capital gains, tax breaks for seniors, write-offs for stock losses, among other things.
8.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

9.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
9.text: Sen. Obama, you proposed $60 billion in tax cuts for middle- income and lower-income people, more tax breaks to create jobs, new spending for public works projects to create jobs.
9.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

10.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
10.text: I will ask both of you: Why is your plan better than his?
10.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

11.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
11.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

12.speaker: McCain:
12.text: Well, let -- let me say, Bob, thank you.
12.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

13.speaker: McCain:
13.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

14.speaker: McCain:
14.text: And, by the way, our beloved Nancy Reagan is in the hospital tonight, so our thoughts and prayers are going with you.
14.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

15.speaker: McCain:
15.text: It's good to see you again, Sen. Obama.
15.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

16.speaker: McCain:
16.text: Americans are hurting right now, and they're angry. They're hurting, and they're angry. They're innocent victims of greed and excess on Wall Street and as well as Washington, D.C. And they're angry, and they have every reason to be angry.
16.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

17.speaker: McCain:
17.text: And they want this country to go in a new direction. And there are elements of my proposal that you just outlined which I won't repeat.
17.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

18.speaker: McCain:
18.text: But we also have to have a short-term fix, in my view, and long- term fixes.
18.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

19.speaker: McCain:
19.text: Let me just talk to you about one of the short-term fixes.
19.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

20.speaker: McCain:
20.text: The catalyst for this housing crisis was the Fannie and Freddie Mae that caused subprime lending situation that now caused the housing market in America to collapse.
20.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

21.speaker: McCain:
21.text: I am convinced that, until we reverse this continued decline in home ownership and put a floor under it, and so that people have not only the hope and belief they can stay in their homes and realize the American dream, but that value will come up.
21.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

22.speaker: McCain:
22.text: Now, we have allocated $750 billion. Let's take 300 of that billion and go in and buy those home loan mortgages and negotiate with those people in their homes, 11 million homes or more, so that they can afford to pay the mortgage, stay in their home.
22.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

23.speaker: McCain:
23.text: Now, I know the criticism of this.
23.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

24.speaker: McCain:
24.text: Well, what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
24.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

25.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
25.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

26.speaker: OBAMA:
26.text: Well, first of all, I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Sen. McCain again, and thank you, Bob.
26.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

27.speaker: OBAMA:
27.text: I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Sen. McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.
27.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

28.speaker: OBAMA:
28.text: And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.
28.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

29.speaker: OBAMA:
29.text: Number one, let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.
29.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

30.speaker: OBAMA:
30.text: Number two, let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200,000, and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.
30.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

31.speaker: OBAMA:
31.text: Now Sen. McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.
31.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

32.speaker: OBAMA:
32.text: I disagree with Sen. McCain in how to do it, because the way Sen. McCain has designed his plan, it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.
32.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

33.speaker: OBAMA:
33.text: Last point I want to make, though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.
33.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

34.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
34.text: All right. Would you like to ask him a question?
34.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

35.speaker: MCCAIN:
35.text: No. I would like to mention that a couple days ago Sen. Obama was out in Ohio and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber, his name is Joe Wurzelbacher.
35.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

36.speaker: MCCAIN:
36.text: Joe wants to buy the business that he has been in for all of these years, worked 10, 12 hours a day. And he wanted to buy the business but he looked at your tax plan and he saw that he was going to pay much higher taxes.
36.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

37.speaker: MCCAIN:
37.text: You were going to put him in a higher tax bracket which was going to increase his taxes, which was going to cause him not to be able to employ people, which Joe was trying to realize the American dream.
37.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

38.speaker: MCCAIN:
38.text: Now Sen. Obama talks about the very, very rich. Joe, I want to tell you, I'll not only help you buy that business that you worked your whole life for and be able -- and I'll keep your taxes low and I'll provide available and affordable health care for you and your employees.
38.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

39.speaker: MCCAIN:
39.text: And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.
39.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

40.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
40.text: Is that what you want to do?
40.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

41.speaker: MCCAIN:
41.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

42.speaker: OBAMA:
42.text: He has been watching ads of Sen. McCain's. Let me tell you what I'm actually going to do. I think tax policy is a major difference between Sen. McCain and myself. And we both want to cut taxes, the difference is who we want to cut taxes for.
42.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

43.speaker: OBAMA:
43.text: Now, Sen. McCain, the centerpiece of his economic proposal is to provide $200 billion in additional tax breaks to some of the wealthiest corporations in America. Exxon Mobil, and other oil companies, for example, would get an additional $4 billion in tax breaks.
43.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

44.speaker: OBAMA:
44.text: What I've said is I want to provide a tax cut for 95 percent of working Americans, 95 percent. If you make more -- if you make less than a quarter million dollars a year, then you will not see your income tax go up, your capital gains tax go up, your payroll tax. Not one dime.
44.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

45.speaker: OBAMA:
45.text: And 95 percent of working families, 95 percent of you out there, will get a tax cut. In fact, independent studies have looked at our respective plans and have concluded that I provide three times the amount of tax relief to middle-class families than Sen. McCain does.
45.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

46.speaker: OBAMA:
46.text: Now, the conversation I had with Joe the plumber, what I essentially said to him was, "Five years ago, when you were in a position to buy your business, you needed a tax cut then."
46.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

47.speaker: OBAMA:
47.text: And what I want to do is to make sure that the plumber, the nurse, the firefighter, the teacher, the young entrepreneur who doesn't yet have money, I want to give them a tax break now. And that requires us to make some important choices.
47.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

48.speaker: OBAMA:
48.text: The last point I'll make about small businesses. Not only do 98 percent of small businesses make less than $250,000, but I also want to give them additional tax breaks, because they are the drivers of the economy. They produce the most jobs.
48.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

49.speaker: MCCAIN:
49.text: You know, when Sen. Obama ended up his conversation with Joe the plumber -- we need to spread the wealth around. In other words, we're going to take Joe's money, give it to Sen. Obama, and let him spread the wealth around.
49.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

50.speaker: MCCAIN:
50.text: I want Joe the plumber to spread that wealth around. You told him you wanted to spread the wealth around.
50.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

51.speaker: MCCAIN:
51.text: The whole premise behind Sen. Obama's plans are class warfare, let's spread the wealth around. I want small businesses -- and by the way, the small businesses that we're talking about would receive an increase in their taxes right now.
51.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

52.speaker: MCCAIN:
52.text: Who -- why would you want to increase anybody's taxes right now? Why would you want to do that, anyone, anyone in America, when we have such a tough time, when these small business people, like Joe the plumber, are going to create jobs, unless you take that money from him and spread the wealth around.
52.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

53.speaker: MCCAIN:
53.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

54.speaker: OBAMA:
54.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

55.speaker: MCCAIN:
55.text: We're not going to do that in my administration.
55.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

56.speaker: OBAMA:
56.text: If I can answer the question. Number one, I want to cut taxes for 95 percent of Americans. Now, it is true that my friend and supporter, Warren Buffett, for example, could afford to pay a little more in taxes in order...
56.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

57.speaker: MCCAIN:
57.text: We're talking about Joe the plumber.
57.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

58.speaker: OBAMA:
58.text: ... in order to give -- in order to give additional tax cuts to Joe the plumber before he was at the point where he could make $250,000.
58.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

59.speaker: OBAMA:
59.text: Then Exxon Mobil, which made $12 billion, record profits, over the last several quarters, they can afford to pay a little more so that ordinary families who are hurting out there -- they're trying to figure out how they're going to afford food, how they're going to save for their kids' college education, they need a break.
59.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

60.speaker: OBAMA:
60.text: So, look, nobody likes taxes. I would prefer that none of us had to pay taxes, including myself. But ultimately, we've got to pay for the core investments that make this economy strong and somebody's got to do it.
60.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

61.speaker: MCCAIN:
61.text: Nobody likes taxes. Let's not raise anybody's taxes. OK?
61.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

62.speaker: OBAMA:
62.text: Well, I don't mind paying a little more.
62.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

63.speaker: MCCAIN:
63.text: The fact is that businesses in America today are paying the second highest tax rate of anywhere in the world. Our tax rate for business in America is 35 percent. Ireland, it's 11 percent.
63.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

64.speaker: MCCAIN:
64.text: Where are companies going to go where they can create jobs and where they can do best in business?
64.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

65.speaker: MCCAIN:
65.text: We need to cut the business tax rate in America. We need to encourage business.
65.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

66.speaker: MCCAIN:
66.text: Now, of all times in America, we need to cut people's taxes. We need to encourage business, create jobs, not spread the wealth around.
66.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

67.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
67.text: All right. Let's go to another topic. It's related. So if you have other things you want to say, you can get back to that.
67.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

68.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
68.text: This question goes to you first, Sen. Obama.
68.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

69.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
69.text: We found out yesterday that this year's deficit will reach an astounding record high $455 billion. Some experts say it could go to $1 trillion next year.
69.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

70.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
70.text: Both of you have said you want to reduce the deficit, but the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget ran the numbers on both of your proposals and they say the cost of your proposals, even with the savings you claim can be made, each will add more than $200 billion to the deficit.
70.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

71.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
71.text: Aren't you both ignoring reality? Won't some of the programs you are proposing have to be trimmed, postponed, even eliminated?
71.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

72.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
72.text: Give us some specifics on what you're going to cut back.
72.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

73.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
73.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

74.speaker: OBAMA:
74.text: Well, first of all, I think it's important for the American public to understand that the $750 billion rescue package, if it's structured properly, and, as president, I will make sure it's structured properly, means that ultimately taxpayers get their money back, and that's important to understand.
74.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

75.speaker: OBAMA:
75.text: But there is no doubt that we've been living beyond our means and we're going to have to make some adjustments.
75.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

76.speaker: OBAMA:
76.text: Now, what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut. I haven't made a promise about...
76.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

77.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
77.text: But you're going to have to cut some of these programs, certainly.
77.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

78.speaker: OBAMA:
78.text: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize, though, is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed, I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.
78.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

79.speaker: OBAMA:
79.text: And some of the cuts, just to give you an example, we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway.
79.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

80.speaker: OBAMA:
80.text: We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line, page by page, programs that don't work, we should cut. Programs that we need, we should make them work better.
80.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

81.speaker: OBAMA:
81.text: Now, what is true is that Sen. McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.
81.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

82.speaker: OBAMA:
82.text: If we make investments now so that people have coverage, that we are preventing diseases, that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.
82.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

83.speaker: OBAMA:
83.text: If we invest in a serious energy policy, that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.
83.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

84.speaker: OBAMA:
84.text: If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college, that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.
84.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

85.speaker: OBAMA:
85.text: But what is absolutely true is that, once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump, that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.
85.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

86.speaker: OBAMA:
86.text: And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility, all of us, corporations, the federal government, and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.
86.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

87.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
87.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

88.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
88.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

89.speaker: MCCAIN:
89.text: Well, thank you, Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era, we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation.
89.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

90.speaker: MCCAIN:
90.text: And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes, and eventually the values of those homes went up, and they actually made money.
90.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

91.speaker: MCCAIN:
91.text: And, by the way, this was a proposal made by Sen. Clinton not too long ago.
91.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

92.speaker: MCCAIN:
92.text: So, obviously, if we can start increasing home values, then there will be creation of wealth.
92.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

93.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
93.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

94.speaker: MCCAIN:
94.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

95.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
95.text: The question was, what are you going to cut?
95.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

96.speaker: MCCAIN:
96.text: Energy -- well, first -- second of all, energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind, tide, solar, natural gas, nuclear, off-shore drilling, which Sen. Obama has opposed.
96.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

97.speaker: MCCAIN:
97.text: And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.
97.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

98.speaker: MCCAIN:
98.text: OK, what -- what would I cut? I would have, first of all, across-the-board spending freeze, OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet, and then I would get out a scalpel, OK?
98.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

99.speaker: MCCAIN:
99.text: Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.
99.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

100.speaker: MCCAIN:
100.text: Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids, a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.
100.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

101.speaker: MCCAIN:
101.text: I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.
101.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

102.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
102.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

103.speaker: MCCAIN:
103.text: I have fought against -- well, one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol.
103.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

104.speaker: MCCAIN:
104.text: I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Sen. Obama supported those subsidies.
104.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

105.speaker: MCCAIN:
105.text: I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.
105.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

106.speaker: MCCAIN:
106.text: I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years, as you might recall, that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer, DOD, and people ended up in jail.
106.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

107.speaker: MCCAIN:
107.text: But I would fight for a line-item veto, and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Sen. Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...
107.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

108.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
108.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

109.speaker: MCCAIN:
109.text: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.
109.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

110.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
110.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

111.speaker: OBAMA:
111.text: Well, look, I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen.
111.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

112.speaker: OBAMA:
112.text: And, in fact, an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet, and we do need a scalpel, because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.
112.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

113.speaker: OBAMA:
113.text: Now, Sen. McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.
113.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

114.speaker: OBAMA:
114.text: Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on, and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.
114.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

115.speaker: OBAMA:
115.text: Now, the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history, just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.
115.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

116.speaker: OBAMA:
116.text: When President Bush came into office, we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.
116.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

117.speaker: OBAMA:
117.text: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars.
117.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

118.speaker: OBAMA:
118.text: So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And, frankly, Sen. McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.
118.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

119.speaker: OBAMA:
119.text: We've got to take this in a new direction, that's what I propose as president.
119.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

120.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
120.text: Do either of you think you can balance the budget in four years? You have said previously you thought you could, Sen. McCain.
120.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

121.speaker: MCCAIN:
121.text: Sure I do. And let me tell you...
121.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

122.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
122.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

123.speaker: MCCAIN:
123.text: Yes. Sen. Obama, I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush, you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country.
123.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

124.speaker: MCCAIN:
124.text: Sen. Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42,000 a year. Of course, we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.
124.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

125.speaker: MCCAIN:
125.text: The mayor of New York, Mayor Bloomberg, just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...
125.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

126.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
126.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

127.speaker: MCCAIN:
127.text: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence.
127.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

128.speaker: MCCAIN:
128.text: Now, look, Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that, and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.
128.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

129.speaker: MCCAIN:
129.text: Sen. Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed.
129.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

130.speaker: MCCAIN:
130.text: He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is, let's look at our records, Sen. Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.
130.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

131.speaker: MCCAIN:
131.text: I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.
131.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

132.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
132.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

133.speaker: OBAMA:
133.text: Well, there's a lot of stuff that was put out there, so let me try to address it. First of all, in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party, the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform, which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers, a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...
133.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

134.speaker: MCCAIN:
134.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

135.speaker: OBAMA:
135.text: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle.
135.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

136.speaker: OBAMA:
136.text: Now with respect to a couple of things Sen. McCain said, the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42,000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Sen. McCain keeps on making.
136.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

137.speaker: OBAMA:
137.text: Even FOX News disputes it, and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies, it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people, on tax policy, on energy policy, on spending priorities, you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.
137.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

138.speaker: OBAMA:
138.text: Now, you've shown independence -- commendable independence, on some key issues like torture, for example, and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies, essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.
138.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

139.speaker: OBAMA:
139.text: And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.
139.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

140.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
140.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

141.speaker: MCCAIN:
141.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

142.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
142.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

143.speaker: MCCAIN:
143.text: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it.
143.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

144.speaker: MCCAIN:
144.text: Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks, whether it be the issue of torture, whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq, which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs, importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.
144.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

145.speaker: MCCAIN:
145.text: I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.
145.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

146.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
146.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

147.speaker: MCCAIN:
147.text: Sen. Obama, your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.
147.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

148.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
148.text: All right. We're going to move to another question and the topic is leadership in this campaign. Both of you pledged to take the high road in this campaign yet it has turned very nasty.
148.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

149.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
149.text: Sen. Obama, your campaign has used words like "erratic," "out of touch," "lie," "angry," "losing his bearings" to describe Sen. McCain.
149.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

150.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
150.text: Sen. McCain, your commercials have included words like "disrespectful," "dangerous," "dishonorable," "he lied." Your running mate said he "palled around with terrorists."
150.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

151.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
151.text: Are each of you tonight willing to sit at this table and say to each other's face what your campaigns and the people in your campaigns have said about each other?
151.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

152.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
152.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

153.speaker: MCCAIN:
153.text: Well, this has been a tough campaign. It's been a very tough campaign. And I know from my experience in many campaigns that, if Sen. Obama had asked -- responded to my urgent request to sit down, and do town hall meetings, and come before the American people, we could have done at least 10 of them by now.
153.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

154.speaker: MCCAIN:
154.text: When Sen. Obama was first asked, he said, "Any place, any time," the way Barry Goldwater and Jack Kennedy agreed to do, before the intervention of the tragedy at Dallas. So I think the tone of this campaign could have been very different.
154.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

155.speaker: MCCAIN:
155.text: And the fact is, it's gotten pretty tough. And I regret some of the negative aspects of both campaigns. But the fact is that it has taken many turns which I think are unacceptable.
155.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

156.speaker: MCCAIN:
156.text: One of them happened just the other day, when a man I admire and respect -- I've written about him -- Congressman John Lewis, an American hero, made allegations that Sarah Palin and I were somehow associated with the worst chapter in American history, segregation, deaths of children in church bombings, George Wallace. That, to me, was so hurtful.
156.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

157.speaker: MCCAIN:
157.text: And, Sen. Obama, you didn't repudiate those remarks. Every time there's been an out-of-bounds remark made by a Republican, no matter where they are, I have repudiated them. I hope that Sen. Obama will repudiate those remarks that were made by Congressman John Lewis, very unfair and totally inappropriate.
157.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

158.speaker: MCCAIN:
158.text: So I want to tell you, we will run a truthful campaign. This is a tough campaign. And it's a matter of fact that Sen. Obama has spent more money on negative ads than any political campaign in history. And I can prove it.
158.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

159.speaker: MCCAIN:
159.text: And, Sen. Obama, when he said -- and he signed a piece of paper that said he would take public financing for his campaign if I did -- that was back when he was a long-shot candidate -- you didn't keep your word.
159.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

160.speaker: MCCAIN:
160.text: And when you looked into the camera in a debate with Sen. Clinton and said, "I will sit down and negotiate with John McCain about public financing before I make a decision," you didn't tell the American people the truth because you didn't.
160.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

161.speaker: MCCAIN:
161.text: And that's -- that's -- that's an unfortunate part. Now we have the highest spending by Sen. Obama's campaign than any time since Watergate.
161.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

162.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
162.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

163.speaker: OBAMA:
163.text: Well, look, you know, I think that we expect presidential campaigns to be tough. I think that, if you look at the record and the impressions of the American people -- Bob, your network just did a poll, showing that two-thirds of the American people think that Sen. McCain is running a negative campaign versus one-third of mine.
163.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

164.speaker: OBAMA:
164.text: And 100 percent, John, of your ads -- 100 percent of them have been negative.
164.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

165.speaker: MCCAIN:
165.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

166.speaker: OBAMA:
166.text: It absolutely is true. And, now, I think the American people are less interested in our hurt feelings during the course of the campaign than addressing the issues that matter to them so deeply.
166.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

167.speaker: OBAMA:
167.text: And there is nothing wrong with us having a vigorous debate like we're having tonight about health care, about energy policy, about tax policy. That's the stuff that campaigns should be made of.
167.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

168.speaker: OBAMA:
168.text: The notion, though, that because we're not doing town hall meetings that justifies some of the ads that have been going up, not just from your own campaign directly, John, but 527s and other organizations that make some pretty tough accusations, well, I don't mind being attacked for the next three weeks.
168.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

169.speaker: OBAMA:
169.text: What the American people can't afford, though, is four more years of failed economic policies. And what they deserve over the next four weeks is that we talk about what's most pressing to them: the economic crisis.
169.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

170.speaker: OBAMA:
170.text: Sen. McCain's own campaign said publicly last week that, if we keep on talking about the economic crisis, we lose, so we need to change the subject.
170.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

171.speaker: OBAMA:
171.text: And I would love to see the next three weeks devoted to talking about the economy, devoted to talking about health care, devoted to talking about energy, and figuring out how the American people can send their kids to college.
171.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

172.speaker: OBAMA:
172.text: And that is something that I would welcome. But it requires, I think, a recognition that politics as usual, as been practiced over the last several years, is not solving the big problems here in America.
172.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

173.speaker: MCCAIN:
173.text: Well, if you'll turn on the television, as I -- I watched the Arizona Cardinals defeat the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday.
173.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

174.speaker: OBAMA:
174.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

175.speaker: MCCAIN:
175.text: Every other ad -- ever other ad was an attack ad on my health care plan. And any objective observer has said it's not true. You're running ads right now that say that I oppose federal funding for stem cell research. I don't.
175.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

176.speaker: MCCAIN:
176.text: You're running ads that misportray completely my position on immigration. So the fact is that Sen. Obama is spending unprecedented -- unprecedented in the history of American politics, going back to the beginning, amounts of money in negative attack ads on me.
176.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

177.speaker: MCCAIN:
177.text: And of course, I've been talking about the economy. Of course, I've talked to people like Joe the plumber and tell him that I'm not going to spread his wealth around. I'm going to let him keep his wealth. And of course, we're talking about positive plan of action to restore this economy and restore jobs in America.
177.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

178.speaker: MCCAIN:
178.text: That's what my campaign is all about and that's what it'll continue to be all about.
178.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

179.speaker: MCCAIN:
179.text: But again, I did not hear a repudiation of Congressman...
179.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

180.speaker: OBAMA:
180.text: I mean, look, if we want to talk about Congressman Lewis, who is an American hero, he, unprompted by my campaign, without my campaign's awareness, made a statement that he was troubled with what he was hearing at some of the rallies that your running mate was holding, in which all the Republican reports indicated were shouting, when my name came up, things like "terrorist" and "kill him," and that you're running mate didn't mention, didn't stop, didn't say "Hold on a second, that's kind of out of line."
180.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

181.speaker: OBAMA:
181.text: And I think Congressman Lewis' point was that we have to be careful about how we deal with our supporters.
181.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

182.speaker: OBAMA:
182.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

183.speaker: MCCAIN:
183.text: You've got to read what he said...
183.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

184.speaker: MCCAIN:
184.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

185.speaker: OBAMA:
185.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

186.speaker: MCCAIN:
186.text: You've got to read what he said.
186.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

187.speaker: OBAMA:
187.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

188.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
188.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

189.speaker: OBAMA:
189.text: ... my response. I do think that he inappropriately drew a comparison between what was happening there and what had happened during the civil rights movement, and we immediately put out a statement saying that we don't think that comparison is appropriate.
189.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

190.speaker: OBAMA:
190.text: And, in fact, afterwards, Congressman Lewis put out a similar statement, saying that he had probably gone over the line.
190.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

191.speaker: OBAMA:
191.text: The important point here is, though, the American people have become so cynical about our politics, because all they see is a tit- for-tat and back-and-forth. And what they want is the ability to just focus on some really big challenges that we face right now, and that's what I have been trying to focus on this entire campaign.
191.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

192.speaker: MCCAIN:
192.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

193.speaker: OBAMA:
193.text: We can have serious differences about our health care policy, for example, John, because we do have a difference on health care policy, but we...
193.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

194.speaker: MCCAIN:
194.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

195.speaker: OBAMA:
195.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

196.speaker: MCCAIN:
196.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

197.speaker: OBAMA:
197.text: But when people suggest that I pal around with terrorists, then we're not talking about issues. What we're talking about...
197.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

198.speaker: MCCAIN:
198.text: Well, let me just say I would...
198.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

199.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
199.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

200.speaker: MCCAIN:
200.text: Let me just say categorically I'm proud of the people that come to our rallies. Whenever you get a large rally of 10,000, 15,000, 20,000 people, you're going to have some fringe peoples. You know that. And I've -- and we've always said that that's not appropriate.
200.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

201.speaker: MCCAIN:
201.text: But to somehow say that group of young women who said "Military wives for McCain" are somehow saying anything derogatory about you, but anything -- and those veterans that wear those hats that say "World War II, Vietnam, Korea, Iraq," I'm not going to stand for people saying that the people that come to my rallies are anything but the most dedicated, patriotic men and women that are in this nation and they're great citizens.
201.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

202.speaker: MCCAIN:
202.text: And I'm not going to stand for somebody saying that because someone yelled something at a rally -- there's a lot of things that have been yelled at your rallies, Sen. Obama, that I'm not happy about either.
202.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

203.speaker: MCCAIN:
203.text: In fact, some T-shirts that are very...
203.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

204.speaker: OBAMA:
204.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

205.speaker: MCCAIN:
205.text: ... unacceptable. So the point is -- the point is that I have repudiated every time someone's been out of line, whether they've been part of my campaign or not, and I will continue to do that.
205.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

206.speaker: MCCAIN:
206.text: But the fact is that we need to absolutely not stand for the kind of things that have been going on. I haven't.
206.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

207.speaker: OBAMA:
207.text: Well, look, Bob, as I said...
207.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

208.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
208.text: I mean, do you take issue with that?
208.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

209.speaker: OBAMA:
209.text: You know, here's what I would say. I mean, we can have a debate back and forth about the merits of each other's campaigns. I suspect we won't agree here tonight.
209.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

210.speaker: OBAMA:
210.text: What I think is most important is that we recognize that to solve the key problems that we're facing, if we're going to solve two wars, the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, if we can -- if we're going to focus on lifting wages that have declined over the last eight years and create jobs here in America, then Democrats, independents and Republicans, we're going to have to be able to work together.
210.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

211.speaker: OBAMA:
211.text: And what is important is making sure that we disagree without being disagreeable. And it means that we can have tough, vigorous debates around issues. What we can't do, I think, is try to characterize each other as bad people. And that has been a culture in Washington that has been taking place for too long. And I think...
211.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

212.speaker: MCCAIN:
212.text: Well, Bob, you asked me a direct question.
212.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

213.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
213.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

214.speaker: MCCAIN:
214.text: Yes, real quick. Mr. Ayers, I don't care about an old washed-up terrorist. But as Sen. Clinton said in her debates with you, we need to know the full extent of that relationship.
214.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

215.speaker: MCCAIN:
215.text: We need to know the full extent of Sen. Obama's relationship with ACORN, who is now on the verge of maybe perpetrating one of the greatest frauds in voter history in this country, maybe destroying the fabric of democracy. The same front outfit organization that your campaign gave $832,000 for "lighting and site selection." So all of these things need to be examined, of course.
215.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

216.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
216.text: All right. I'm going to let you respond and we'll extend this for a moment.
216.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

217.speaker: OBAMA:
217.text: Bob, I think it's going to be important to just -- I'll respond to these two particular allegations that Sen. McCain has made and that have gotten a lot of attention.
217.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

218.speaker: OBAMA:
218.text: In fact, Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Sen. McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.
218.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

219.speaker: OBAMA:
219.text: Forty years ago, when I was 8 years old, he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group. I have roundly condemned those acts. Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends, Mr. Annenberg.
219.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

220.speaker: OBAMA:
220.text: Other members on that board were the presidents of the University of Illinois, the president of Northwestern University, who happens to be a Republican, the president of The Chicago Tribune, a Republican- leaning newspaper.
220.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

221.speaker: OBAMA:
221.text: Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.
221.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

222.speaker: OBAMA:
222.text: Now, with respect to ACORN, ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks, and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people, they just filled out a bunch of names.
222.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

223.speaker: OBAMA:
223.text: It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.
223.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

224.speaker: OBAMA:
224.text: Now, the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Sen. McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.
224.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

225.speaker: OBAMA:
225.text: Let me tell you who I associate with. On economic policy, I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker. If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy, I associate myself with my running mate, Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar, the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, or General Jim Jones, the former supreme allied commander of NATO.
225.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

226.speaker: OBAMA:
226.text: Those are the people, Democrats and Republicans, who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House. And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign, Sen. McCain, says more about your campaign than it says about me.
226.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

227.speaker: MCCAIN:
227.text: Well, again, while you were on the board of the Woods Foundation, you and Mr. Ayers, together, you sent $230,000 to ACORN. So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.
227.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

228.speaker: OBAMA:
228.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

229.speaker: MCCAIN:
229.text: And the facts are facts and records are records.
229.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

230.speaker: OBAMA:
230.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

231.speaker: MCCAIN:
231.text: And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Sen. Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more, and he had a long association with him. It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Sen. Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment.
231.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

232.speaker: MCCAIN:
232.text: And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track, about creating jobs, about a brighter future for America. And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Sen. Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy. And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.
232.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

233.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
233.text: All right. Let's go to the next topic and you -- we may want to get back into some of this during this next discussion. I want to ask both of you about the people that you're going to bring into the government.
233.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

234.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
234.text: And our best insight yet is who you have picked as your running mates.
234.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

235.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
235.text: So I'll begin by asking both of you this question, and I'll ask you to answer first, Sen. Obama. Why would the country be better off if your running mate became president rather than his running mate?
235.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

236.speaker: OBAMA:
236.text: Well, Joe Biden, I think, is one of the finest public servants that has served in this country. It's not just that he has some of the best foreign policy credentials of anybody. And Democrats and Republicans alike, I think, acknowledge his expertise there.
236.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

237.speaker: OBAMA:
237.text: But it's also that his entire life he has never forgotten where he came from, coming from Scranton, fighting on behalf of working families, remembering what it's like to see his father lose his job and go through a downward spiral economically.
237.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

238.speaker: OBAMA:
238.text: And, as a consequence, his consistent pattern throughout his career is to fight for the little guy. That's what he's done when it comes to economic policies that will help working families get a leg up.
238.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

239.speaker: OBAMA:
239.text: That's what he's done when it comes to, for example, passing the landmark 1994 crime bill, the Violence Against Women's Act. Joe has always made sure that he is fighting on behalf of working families, and I think he shares my core values and my sense of where the country needs to go.
239.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

240.speaker: OBAMA:
240.text: Because after eight years of failed policies, he and I both agree that what we're going to have to do is to re-prioritize, make sure that we're investing in the American people, give tax cuts not to the wealthiest corporations, but give them to small businesses and give them to individuals who are struggling right now, make sure that we finally get serious about energy independence, something that has been languishing in Washington for 30 years, and make sure that our kids get a great education and can afford to go to college.
240.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

241.speaker: OBAMA:
241.text: So, on the key issues that are of importance to American families, Joe Biden's always been on the right side, and I think he will make an outstanding president if, heaven forbid, something happened to me.
241.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

242.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
242.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

243.speaker: MCCAIN:
243.text: Well, Americans have gotten to know Sarah Palin. They know that she's a role model to women and other -- and reformers all over America.
243.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

244.speaker: MCCAIN:
244.text: She's a reformer. She is -- she took on a governor who was a member of her own party when she ran for governor. When she was the head of their energy and natural resources board, she saw corruption, she resigned and said, "This can't go on."
244.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

245.speaker: MCCAIN:
245.text: She's given money back to the taxpayers. She's cut the size of government. She negotiated with the oil companies and faced them down, a $40 billion pipeline of natural gas that's going to relieve the energy needs of the United -- of what they call the lower 48.
245.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

246.speaker: MCCAIN:
246.text: She's a reformer through and through. And it's time we had that bresh of freth air (sic) -- breath of fresh air coming into our nation's capital and sweep out the old-boy network and the cronyism that's been so much a part of it that I've fought against for all these years.
246.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

247.speaker: MCCAIN:
247.text: She'll be my partner. She understands reform. And, by the way, she also understands special-needs families. She understands that autism is on the rise, that we've got to find out what's causing it, and we've got to reach out to these families, and help them, and give them the help they need as they raise these very special needs children.
247.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

248.speaker: MCCAIN:
248.text: She understands that better than almost any American that I know. I'm proud of her.
248.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

249.speaker: MCCAIN:
249.text: And she has ignited our party and people all over America that have never been involved in the political process. And I can't tell how proud I am of her and her family.
249.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

250.speaker: MCCAIN:
250.text: Her husband's a pretty tough guy, by the way, too.
250.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

251.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
251.text: Do you think she's qualified to be president?
251.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

252.speaker: OBAMA:
252.text: You know, I think it's -- that's going to be up to the American people. I think that, obviously, she's a capable politician who has, I think, excited the -- a base in the Republican Party.
252.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

253.speaker: OBAMA:
253.text: And I think it's very commendable the work she's done on behalf of special needs. I agree with that, John.
253.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

254.speaker: OBAMA:
254.text: I do want to just point out that autism, for example, or other special needs will require some additional funding, if we're going to get serious in terms of research. That is something that every family that advocates on behalf of disabled children talk about.
254.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

255.speaker: OBAMA:
255.text: And if we have an across-the-board spending freeze, we're not going to be able to do it. That's an example of, I think, the kind of use of the scalpel that we want to make sure that we're funding some of those programs.
255.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

256.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
256.text: Do you think Sen. Biden is qualified?
256.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

257.speaker: MCCAIN:
257.text: I think that Joe Biden is qualified in many respects. But I do point out that he's been wrong on many foreign policy and national security issues, which is supposed to be his strength.
257.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

258.speaker: MCCAIN:
258.text: He voted against the first Gulf War. He voted against it and, obviously, we had to take Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait or it would've threatened the Middle Eastern world supply.
258.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

259.speaker: MCCAIN:
259.text: In Iraq, he had this cockamamie idea about dividing Iraq into three countries. We're seeing Iraq united as Iraqis, tough, hard, but we're seeing them. We're now about to have an agreement for status of forces in Iraq coming up.
259.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

260.speaker: MCCAIN:
260.text: There are several issues in which, frankly, Joe Biden and I open and honestly disagreed on national security policy, and he's been wrong on a number of the major ones.
260.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

261.speaker: MCCAIN:
261.text: But again, I want to come back to, notice every time Sen. Obama says, "We need to spend more, we need to spend more, that's the answer" -- why do we always have to spend more?
261.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

262.speaker: MCCAIN:
262.text: Why can't we have transparency, accountability, reform of these agencies of government? Maybe that's why he's asked for 860 -- sought and proposed $860 billion worth of new spending and wants to raise people's taxes in a time of incredible challenge and difficulty and heartache for the American families.
262.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

263.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
263.text: Let's go to -- let's go to a new topic. We're running a little behind.
263.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

264.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
264.text: Let's talk about energy and climate control. Every president since Nixon has said what both of you...
264.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

265.speaker: MCCAIN:
265.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

266.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
266.text: Climate change, yes -- has said what both of you have said, and, that is, we must reduce our dependence on foreign oil.
266.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

267.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
267.text: When Nixon said it, we imported from 17 to 34 percent of our foreign oil. Now, we're importing more than 60 percent.
267.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

268.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
268.text: Would each of you give us a number, a specific number of how much you believe we can reduce our foreign oil imports during your first term?
268.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

269.speaker: SCHIEFFER:
269.text: And I believe the first question goes to you, Sen. McCain.
269.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

270.speaker: MCCAIN:
270.text: I think we can, for all intents and purposes, eliminate our dependence on Middle Eastern oil and Venezuelan oil. Canadian oil is fine.
270.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York

271.speaker: MCCAIN:
